SUNSCREENS MAY NOT BLOCK WORST SKIN CANCERS

Non-subscribers can make individual purchase by calling
212-556-4204 or 1927.)  
 (JT)  
 By JANE E. BRODY   
 c.1998 N.Y. Times News Service   

   Just when dermatologists and cancer specialists had Americans
convinced that sunscreens could protect them from skin cancer and
wrinkles, a scientist at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in
New York concluded after a review of available research that
sunscreens might not prevent melanoma, the deadliest form of skin
cancer, at least not the way products were formulated and used in
the 1980s. This news is particularly significant given the rising
rates of melanoma.

   The scientist, Dr. Marianne Berwick, even suggested that an
overdependence on sunscreens might actually increase the risk of
melanoma in susceptible people because sunscreens prevent sunburn
well enough to allow users to spend more time in the sun than they
otherwise might, without providing adequate protection against skin
cancer.

   The report, presented in February to the American Association
for the Advancement of Science, set back decades of public health
education and left many wondering if medical science would ever get
it right.

   But before you leap to the unwarranted conclusion that you have
been duped once again by the health police, a closer look at the
effects of sunlight on skin and the effectiveness and proper use of
sunscreens is in order.

   Ultraviolet B, or UVB, radiation is the principal cause of
sunburn. The sun protection factor, or SPF, stated on sunscreen
products refers primarily to their capacity to block UVB radiation;
the higher the SPF rating, the longer a user can remain in sunlight
without burning.

   Most sunscreen products have little or no protection against
Ultraviolet A, or UVA, the principal form of radiation emitted in
tanning booths, which causes premature aging of the skin _ the
wrinkled, leathery skin common among sun worshipers over 50 years
of age. UVA radiation is also considered the primary rays involved
in skin cancer.

   While not minimizing the dangers of UVA, new research points to
the hazards of UVB rays. A study published in June by Dr. Ercem
Atillasoy, a dermatologist affiliated with the Wistar Institute and
Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia, demonstrated for the
first time that UVB radiation can also cause two of the deadliest
but least common forms of skin cancer, squamous cell carcinoma and
melanoma.

   After testing the effects of UVB on human skin transplanted onto
immune-deficient mice, however, Atillasoy was surprised to find
that the most common form of skin cancer, basal cell carcinoma, did
not develop. He suspects that this cancer, which most often occurs
on the face, ears and other sun-exposed parts of the body and is
diagnosed in more than a million Americans each year, must be
caused by UVA radiation. He plans to examine this hypothesis with
similar mice with transplanted human skin.

   Before Atillasoy's study, there were no good animal models in
which to study human melanoma, in which other factors besides
sunlight play a role. Genetics, for example, is an important
factor. Fair-skinned people who do not tan easily, those with lots
of moles and those with a family history of skin cancer are more
likely than dark-skinned people to develop all forms of skin
cancer, including melanoma. And about 5 percent of melanomas occur
on the soles of the feet, palms of the hands and in the mouth and
sinuses, areas that are not exposed to sunlight, said Dr. Allan
Halpern, chief of dermatology at Memorial Sloan-Kettering.

   ``This means that in about 95 percent of cases of melanoma, sun
exposure plays a role, directly or indirectly,'' Halpern said.

   ``The scientific data, although imperfect, are still very strong
that there is a link between UV and melanoma,'' he added. ``We
still need to work out the details _ the specific wavelengths, the
doses and the timing _ but there is good evidence to suggest that
both UVB and UVA are involved.''

   Among the unknowns is the importance of sun exposure in
childhood. Some research suggests that severe sunburns in childhood
set the stage for later development of melanoma. Childhood sun
exposure may be the initiating event that plants the seeds of a
cancer, but repeated sun exposure in adult life may be what
promotes the full-scale growth of cancer.

   Also uncertain is the effect of the intensity and frequency of
sun exposure. People like farmers and fishermen who are always in
the sun get lots of basal cell carcinomas but have no greater risk
of melanoma than others less intensely exposed to sunlight. Halpern
said that repeated ``bursts'' of sunlight may be worse for
developing melanoma than continuous exposure, which would bode ill
for indoor workers who spend their leisure hours in the sun.

   Dr. Berwick said she did not intend to discourage people from
using sunscreens, but rather wanted to emphasize that these
products were perhaps the least important step in preventing
melanoma and other skin cancers. First and foremost, she and others
insist, is to stay out of the sun as much as possible, especially
when it is most directly overhead _ from about 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. in
the summer and 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. in the winter. Keep in mind that
cloud cover provides little protection against UV exposure.

   Step 2 is to keep covered up when outdoors and not in the shade
by wearing a wide-brimmed hat, long sleeves and long pants, as well
as UV-blocking sunglasses to protect the eyes. However, few experts
have great hopes that Americans will heed such clothing advice when
temperatures rise above 80 degrees or before the problem of ``hat
hair'' is solved.

   Step 3 is to use a lip balm with an SPF rating of 15 and
liberally apply sunscreen with an SPF rating of 15 or higher on all
sun-exposed parts of the body every time you are outdoors. If you
are wearing a bathing suit, use at least one ounce of sunscreen to
cover exposed skin. Apply it at least half an hour before going out
and reapply it every few hours, even if the product is said to be
``water resistant'' or to provide ``all day'' protection.

   Some of the newer products, called sun blocks, protect against
UVA as well as UVB radiation. But all sun blocks are not equally
effective. Avobenzone (also called Parsol 1789) and oxybenzone do
not screen out as much UVA as titanium dioxide and zinc oxide. Zinc
oxide, the white paste that lifeguards often use on their noses and
lips, is the most effective sun block.

   A new micronized, transparent form of zinc oxide has been
developed by Dr. Mark Mitchnick, a pediatrician who is the medical
director of Sunsmart, a New York company that makes micronized zinc
oxide (sold as Z-Cote). That product has been incorporated into
some sun protection products, including the sunscreens Iguana, Key
West Aloe Sunsorb and the Body Shop SPF 30 stick and SPF 6 spray.
It is also in Skinceuticals' moisturizers with sunscreen, Daily Sun
Defense and Ultimate UV Defense, and will be introduced this year
into the Procter & Gamble Co.'s Oil of Olay, the nation's leading
moisturizer with sunscreen. Zinc oxide's physical protection may be
preferred by people sensitive to chemical sun blocks.
